Award.AbstractNarration:
The conference "Recent Advances in Algebraic Geometry" will be held May 16--19, 2013 at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. The motivation behind the conference is the extraordinary progress made in the past decade in our understanding of the geometry of higher dimensional algebraic varieties, as well as in areas such as Hodge theory, enumerative geometry, or syzygies. It will bring together leading experts in Algebraic Geometry, to inform the audience of the major developments of the past few years, to propose new research directions, and to establish connections between different subfields. The following themes will be represented at the conference: the Minimal Model Program and its applications, vanishing theorems and multiplier ideals, derived categories and applications, Hodge theory and complex geometry, moduli spaces and enumerative geometry, commutative and computational algebra. More details about the conference, as well as the list of confirmed speakers, are available at the conference website, at http://homepages.math.uic.edu/~mpopa/robfest/

The conference will focus on some of the outstanding recent developments in Algebraic Geometry. The speakers have been chosen on the basis of their research contributions to the field, but also for their expository skills and dedication to the development of younger generations of researchers and teachers in mathematics. Some have produced many of the most important textbooks and advanced monographs in Algebraic Geometry in the last decades, have introduced many of today's algebraic geometers to active research topics, and have been a major force in developing the field as a whole. We therefore expect the conference to be well-attended by young researchers wishing to learn about, and then share with members of their groups, current questions in a wide spectrum of topics. The talks will contain a substantial expository and didactic component for this younger audience, for whom it is sometimes difficult to keep up to date with the rapid developments that the field is seeing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This document reports on the outcome of the conference \emph{Recent advances in algebraic geometry}. The past decade has seen tremendous progress in several areas of algebraic geometry. In birational geometry, several long-standing conjectures have been proved and this in turn led to a flurry of applications in related directions, such as the birational study of moduli spaces or the construction of compactifications of moduli spaces of varieties of general type. At the same time, recent years have seen important developments in areas such as Hodge theory, enumerative algebraic geometry, or syzygies, sometimes based on techniques overlapping with those in birational geometry.

 

The primary purpose of this conference was to give a panorama of the directions that have seen many recent developments, by inviting to speak some of the leading experts working in these fields. There were 13 talks, covering areas such as birational geometry, singularities, derived categories, matrix factorizations, syzygies, Hodge theory, as well as topics of classical flavor like degeneracy loci or K3 and Enriques surfaces. According to our request to the speakers, the talks had a substantial expository and didactic component for the younger audience, for whom it is sometimes difficult to keep up-to-date with the rapid developments that the field has seen lately.

 Overall the conference was a success. The topics covered and the outstanding list of speakers have attracted a lot of interest and there were 149 registered participants.The talks were of very high quality, the speakers making a special effort to make the talks accessible to a broad audience, half of which consisted of graduate students and postdocs. Both for the young participants and for the more senior people in the audience it was a great opportunity to see an overview of some exciting recent results in algebraic geometry.

Based upon the feedback from students and junior researchers, we also feel that the educational component of the conference has been successful. There was also a poster session in which 10 young participants presented their work.

In order to maximize the dissemination of the results and open problems discussed at the meeting, the organizers edited a Conference Proceedings volume, containing both research contributions and expository articles. The volume titled ``Recent Advances in Algebraic Geometry" appeared at the beginning of 2015.
